author: By Debra Weiner
title: What the C.E.O. of Pfizer and Other Covid-19 Fighters Learned From Their Parents
description: Various people working to stop the pandemic reflected on the life skills their parents taught them: determination, teamwork, resilience and more.
content: Debra Weiner interviewed people who are working to beat the coronavirus about the most valuable things their parents taught them. Following are excerpts from a few of those stories, edited and condensed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: Biden Plans to Restore Alaskan Forest Protections Stripped Under Trump
description: The administration says it will “repeal or replace” the rule that opened up more than half of Tongass National Forest to logging.
content: The Biden administration plans to restore environmental protections to Tongass National Forest in Alaska, one of the world’s largest intact temperate rain forests, that had been stripped away by former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Dreyfus
title: Why Some Orthodox Jewish Women Won’t Get Vaccinated
description: Unsubstantiated rumors about the coronavirus vaccine and fertility have dissuaded some young women in New York’s Orthodox Jewish communities from getting the vaccine.
content: In April, rumors began swirling in various New York City neighborhoods with large Orthodox Jewish communities about how the coronavirus vaccine could pose a serious threat to women’s fertility.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: Kim Jong-un Calls K-Pop a ‘Vicious Cancer’ in the New Culture War
description: South Korean music, movies and dramas are winning the hearts of young North Koreans. Their influence is seen as a threat to Mr. Kim’s grip on society.
content: SEOUL — Kim Jong-un called it a “vicious cancer” corrupting young North Koreans’ “attire, hairstyles, speeches, behaviors.” His state media has warned that if left unchecked, it would make North Korea “crumble like a damp wall.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: Merrick Garland announces Justice Dept. plans to protect voting access.
description: The attorney general says he will add to voting-rights law enforcement staff and scrutinize new laws that curb voter access.
content: Attorney General Merrick B. Garland laid out a detailed plan on Friday for protecting voting rights, announcing that the Justice Department would double enforcement staff on the issue, scrutinize new laws that seek to curb voter access and act if it sees a violation of federal law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: For the Juiciest Grilled Chicken, Just Add Yogurt
description: A staple of South and Central Asian cooking, a yogurt marinade preps proteins to take the heat.
content: Of all the things to get excited about as grilling season kicks in — the crisp-edged pork butt, the herb-rubbed lamb legs, all those resplendent peppers and eggplants and burgers galore — humble chicken thighs fall to the bottom of the list.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: In Australia, a New Look at Immigration: ‘It’s About Our Friends’
description: In a country inured to criticism over its migrant policies, a case involving a 3-year-old detainee who ended up hospitalized has drawn outrage.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — The 3-year-old girl was born in Australia, in a tiny town called Biloela, far from the big cities of Sydney and Melbourne. But her parents were asylum seekers from Sri Lanka and living in a country that heavily discourages illegal migration, so the government sent them to a faraway island while deciding their fate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Chiu
title: Overlooked No More: Jobriath, Openly Gay Glam Rocker in the ’70s
description: His space alien persona and theatrical rock music drew comparisons to David Bowie’s Ziggy Stardust character. But American audiences seemed unwilling to accept his sexuality.
content: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Rose Byrne and Annie Weisman Get Into ‘Physical’
description: In an interview, the star and creator of the new Apple TV+ comedy discuss aerobics, ’80s perms and the dark personal experiences that inspired the show.
content: In the first moments of “Physical,” a new series debuting June 18 on Apple TV+, Sheila (Rose Byrne), a homemaker in San Diego, Calif., looks in the mirror. She doesn’t like what she sees. “Look at you,” she says to herself in a vicious voice-over. “I mean, seriously. Do you really think you’re pulling this whole thing off? The disco sex kitten look? At your age?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill McKibben
title: The Keystone XL Pipeline Is Dead. Next Target: Line 3.
description: The fight over the pipeline will be, at least for now, where Biden’s climate commitment will be judged.
content: The announcement this week from the Canadian company TC Energy that it was pulling the plug on the Keystone XL pipeline project was greeted with jubilation by Indigenous groups, farmers and ranchers, climate scientists and other activists who have spent the last decade fighting its construction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Rothman and Shaina Feinberg
title: Gen Z Teens Talk $
description: Allowance, holidays and … cryptocurrency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Perceived Grievances Drove Virginia Beach Gunman to Kill 12, F.B.I. Finds
description: DeWayne Craddock, a city engineer who went on a shooting rampage in 2019, had been “fixated for years” on criticism at work, the F.B.I. said.
content: A city engineer was obsessed for years with perceived workplace grievances before killing 12 people in a 2019 shooting at a municipal complex in Virginia Beach, the F.B.I. said this week, releasing the findings of a behavioral analysis that provided new insight on a motive for the attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: We Know Nothing About Harry Kane
description: He is England’s captain, Tottenham’s goal machine and a Tom Brady superfan. But as transfer talk swirls and Euro 2020 begins, he reveals only what he wants you to see.
content: Follow our live Euro 2020 coverage here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Review: Christopher Wheeldon Creates a Memorable Realm
description: Wheeldon’s “Curious Kingdom,” on a Pacific Northwest Ballet program with two premieres, achieves moments of exquisite beauty.
content: Christopher Wheeldon’s new work for Pacific Northwest Ballet is called “Curious Kingdom.” Since the music is all French, the title might refer to France, though it’s been a long time since that country had a king. Or perhaps the alliterative phrase and its “Alice in Wonderland” adjective allude to contemporary ballet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Eavis
title: Meager Rewards for Workers, Exceptionally Rich Pay for C.E.O.s
description: The gap between workers and C.E.O.s widened during the pandemic as public companies granted top executives some of the richest pay packages ever.
content: Even in a gilded age for executive pay, 2020 was a blowout year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Wegman
title: A Humane Judge, Gone Too Soon
description: Robert Katzmann, who had been a top federal judge, died this week at age 68.
content: “Nothing human can be perfect,” Gouverneur Morris, the founding father, wrote in a letter to a friend in 1815. He was referring to the drafting of the Constitution, a long and contentious process in which he had played a central role three decades earlier. “Surrounded by difficulties, we did the best we could; leaving it with those who should come after us to take counsel from experience.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: A More Perfect Union
description: Sasha Issenberg talks about “The Engagement,” and J. Hoberman discusses the story of Hollywood as told through 10 books.
content: “The Engagement,” by Sasha Issenberg, recounts the complex and chaotic chain reaction that thrust same-sex marriage from the realm of conservative conjecture to the top of the gay political agenda and, eventually, to the halls of the Supreme Court. On this week’s podcast, Issenberg talks about the deeply researched book, which covers 25 years of legal and cultural history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Gladstone
title: Iran Pays Delinquent U.N. Dues, Getting Its Vote Back
description: The $16.2 million was drawn from Iranian money in a Korean bank that had been frozen by U.S. sanctions but was freed to pay the dues — apparently a conciliatory signal by the Biden administration.
content: Using bank funds freed from American sanctions, Iran has paid $16.2 million in delinquent dues owed to the United Nations, diplomats said Friday, a step that restored Iran’s suspended voting rights at the world body.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Pulitzer Prizes Focus on Coverage of Pandemic and Law Enforcement
description: The annual awards recognized journalism on the murder of George Floyd, including a special citation for Darnella Frazier, the teenager who filmed the killing. The public service prize went to The New York Times for Covid coverage.
content: Pulitzer Prizes were awarded on Friday to news organizations that provided in-depth coverage of the dramatic turns of 2020, a year dominated by a pandemic that left millions dead and a national conversation on race after the murder of George Floyd.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Remember the Super League? That fight isn’t over.
description: While today’s news is the start of Euro 2020, the repercussions of the biggest crisis in the continent’s club scene are not over.

title: Didi Chuxing, a ride-hailing behemoth in China, reveals I.P.O. papers.
description: The company said it intended to finance an expansion.
content: Didi Chuxing, the Chinese ride-hailing company, made its initial public offering filing public on Thursday, as ride-hailing services begin reviving with the receding of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Denny Agassi
title: He Made Affection Feel Simple
description: Dating as a transgender woman, in my experience, meant low expectations and casual sex. Then I met Jack.
content: My bio on Grindr read: “Be trans friendly. Send face to chat.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Marris
title: The Case Against Zoos
description: Many of them aspire to be good civic institutions that care for animals on their grounds and in the wild. But is it really worth their captivity?
content: After being captives of the pandemic for more than a year, we have begun experiencing the pleasures of simple outings: dining al fresco, shopping with a friend, taking a stroll through the zoo. As we snap a selfie by the sea lions for the first time in so long, it seems worth asking, after our collective ordeal, whether our pleasure in seeing wild animals up close is worth the price of their captivity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Wonking Out: Economic Nationalism, Biden-Style
description: China is the new Japan, and chips are the new chips.
content: If you’re under 50, you probably don’t remember when Japan was going to take over the world. But in the late 1980s and early 1990s, many people were obsessed with Japan’s economic success and feared American decline. The supposedly nonfiction sections of airport bookstores were filled with volumes featuring samurai warriors on their covers, promising to teach you the secrets of Japanese management. Michael Crichton had a best-selling novel, “Rising Sun,” about the looming threat of Japanese domination, before he moved on to dinosaurs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Winkelman
title: ‘Wish Dragon’ Review: ‘Aladdin’ Goes to Shanghai, Sort Of
description: John Cho, as Long the dragon, does his best Robin Williams impression in this film animation about a teenage boy who releases him from a magic teapot.
content: In the engaging animated feature “Wish Dragon,” a teenage boy comes into possession of a magic teapot containing a world-weary dragon who’s obliged to grant him three wishes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: Vaccinate the World
description: Wealthy countries are pledging to donate a billion doses. Will it be enough?
content: Roughly 20 percent of the world’s people have received at least one shot of a Covid-19 vaccine. The speed with which the remaining 80 percent are vaccinated will mean the difference between life and death for a staggering number of people — probably in the millions.
source.name: The New York Times

source.name: The New York Times

title: America May Be ‘Back’ in Europe, but How Much Has Really Changed?
description: Despite the feel-good imagery expected to be on display at the Group of 7 meeting, many Europeans suspect that President Biden is little more interested in give-and-take than was his predecessor.
content: FALMOUTH, England — Few images captured the rupture in trans-Atlantic relations better than that of President Donald J. Trump in 2018, arms folded across his chest as he resisted Chancellor Angela Merkel and other frustrated leaders in their doomed effort to salvage their summit meeting in Canada.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas, Daisuke Wakabayashi and Katie Benner
title: In Leak Investigation, Tech Giants Are Caught Between Courts and Customers
description: Apple, under fire for turning over the data of two lawmakers to the Trump Justice Dept., said it did so unknowingly, while Google fought a request for New York Times data because it related to a corporate client.
content: On Feb. 6, 2018, Apple received a grand jury subpoena for the names and phone records connected to 109 email addresses and phone numbers. It was one of the more than 250 data requests that the company received on average from U.S. law enforcement each week at the time. An Apple paralegal complied and provided the information.
source.name: The New York Times

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Nicholson
title: Four Secrets About ‘Raiders of the Lost Ark’
description: As Steven Spielberg’s classic adventure celebrates its 40th anniversary, here are behind-the-scenes stories of dizzy rats, raucous boulders and friendly flies.

author: By Gabriel Schoenfeld
title: Leaking the Pentagon Papers Was an Assault on Democracy
description: The way we control secrets has been established by Congress and the executive branch, both accountable to the public and the courts. Daniel Ellsberg, accountable to no one, took it upon himself to steer the ship of state.
content: It is an axiom that governmental secrecy is antithetical to democratic self-rule. But it is also an axiom that secrecy is crucial to the conduct of statecraft. The 50th anniversary of the publication of the Pentagon Papers by The New York Times provides an occasion to consider what happens when the two axioms collide. The case of Daniel Ellsberg, perhaps the most celebrated leaker in our history, reveals the ambiguities stemming from a tension that can never be satisfactorily resolved.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle and Benjamin Mueller
title: ‘Freedom Day’ for England Is Looking Like a Mirage
description: All coronavirus restrictions were supposed to end on June 21, but with the new Delta variant, the long-anticipated opening is increasingly problematic.
content: LONDON — The news media call it “freedom day,” the fast approaching moment when England’s remaining coronavirus restrictions are scheduled to be cast off at last, allowing pubs to fill to capacity, nightclubs to open their doors and the curtain to rise in theaters around the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Biden’s approaches to Europe.
content: President Biden will convene with European leaders today in Cornwall, England, where he is expected to make a show of partnership and solidarity. But it is not clear how much more open the U.S. will be to a give-and-take with Europe than it was under Donald Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: ‘Lupin’ Took the World by Stealth. Part 2 Can’t Be So Sneaky.
description: The French heist thriller was a huge global hit when it debuted on Netflix in January. Even the creator and cast were surprised.
content: Anybody who claims to have foreseen the sweeping, worldwide success of the Netflix series “Lupin” is probably engaging in a bit of revisionist history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: Consider the $34 Lobster Roll
description: The pandemic has exacerbated a price spike in the iconic New England summer sandwich.
content: WISCASSET, Maine — On the first weekend of June, the scene at Red’s Eats seemed much like summers past. The line of tourists waiting to order at this picturesque seafood shack ran down the block. The sun beat down and employees passed out umbrellas and water, the sort of nicety you provide when your restaurant makes “best of” lists and causes traffic jams in attracting people from across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Biden and the E.U. hope to settle a trade dispute and end billions in tariffs.
description: As President Biden and European Union leaders prepare to meet at a summit in Brussels next week, they are working toward an agreement that would settle long-running disputes over aircraft subsidies and tariffs on a wide range of products, which escalated during the Trump administration.
content: As President Biden and European Union leaders prepare to meet at a summit in Brussels next week, they are working toward an agreement that would settle long-running disputes over aircraft subsidies and tariffs on a wide range of products, which escalated during the Trump administration.

author: By Melena Ryzik
title: A Film Tries to Make a Difference for Domestic Violence Survivors
description: “And So I Stayed” examines how the courts treat women who kill their abusers. The movie played a role in one case that resulted in freedom after a conviction.
content: In 2013, Tanisha Davis, a 26-year-old woman from Rochester, N.Y., was sentenced to 14 years in prison for killing her boyfriend, at whose hands she suffered, she said, nearly seven years of abuse, including choking, death threats and a beating on the night he died. The judge agreed that she was a victim of domestic violence but said her response did not merit leniency. “You handled the situation all wrong,” he told her. “You could have left.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Racist Mural Puts Tate Galleries in a Bind
description: Problematic sections of a work painted on Tate Britain’s walls have caught museum officials between the demands of activists and the policies of the British government.
content: LONDON — Since Tate Britain reopened last month after a five-month pandemic shutdown, the museum has been bustling. Visitors in masks have roamed its galleries, halls and atrium again, enjoying the huge collection of British art, from 16th-century portraits to contemporary installations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Ravaged and Resilient, the Show Goes On
description: Euro 2020 will not be the tournament anyone wanted, and it arrives after a year few will care to remember. And yet, once it starts, all of that will fall away.
content: This is not how it was meant to be. The stands were supposed to be full, the cities jubilant, the lights of a carnival illuminating a continent. Euro 2020 was supposed to be the moment when it all began again, the great symbol of a world returning to normal. That is not how the tournament is. Instead, it is all it can be, how it has to be.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Daily: Our Country Is Being Hacked
description: And what you can do about it. Plus, telling the story of two women whose work has shaped the world.
content: Hi everyone, Happy Friday. We had a busy week exploring some big questions: Will Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel fall? Who is hacking the U.S. economy? And what could possibly have brought Congress together in a rare act of bipartisanship (even if only for a moment)?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola and Jason Gutierrez
title: Italy halts the use of AstraZeneca’s vaccine in those under 60, and other news from around the world.
description: The decision was the latest in a series of reversals for the vaccine, and Italian health experts fear damage to the country’s vaccination campaign.
content: Italy will stop administering AstraZeneca’s Covid vaccine to people under the age of 60, the Italian government announced on Friday, amid a drop in the country’s level of infections that meant the risks of distributing the vaccine to younger people was judged to outweigh the benefits.
source.name: The New York Times

content: In the 1990s, the composer Tania León was named a new-music adviser to the New York Philharmonic. But the orchestra did not play any of her work back then.

author: By Peter S. Goodman
title: Europe’s Summer of Recovery Is More Fragile Than It Looks
description: An anticipated surge of tourism in Portugal is suddenly not at all certain — a symbol of the global economy’s continued struggle with pandemic uncertainty.
content: ALBUFEIRA, Portugal — Until last week, Raissa Moura and her co-workers at the reception desk of the Pine Cliffs Resort were feeling optimistic that life was returning to normal along Portugal’s southern coast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Badger
title: A Little More Remote Work Could Change Rush Hour a Lot
description: Peak commute time has long ruled our lives, our cities, our tax dollars. But it doesn’t have to.
content: There is something uniquely awful about that time of day when there is no good way to get around. The car horns sound nastier as downtown traffic snarls. The elbows feel sharper on a jammed subway. The sight of red brake lights is soul-crushing when they lead on a highway all the way to the horizon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang
title: Lawmakers, Taking Aim at Big Tech, Push Sweeping Overhaul of Antitrust
description: A bipartisan group of House members introduced five bills targeting Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google.
content: WASHINGTON — House lawmakers on Friday introduced sweeping antitrust legislation aimed at restraining the power of Big Tech and staving off corporate consolidation. If passed, the bills would be the most ambitious update to monopoly laws in decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: A Recharged New York, Through Young Eyes
description: For a special project of The Times Magazine, 15 photographers ages 25 and under captured an electric, joyous, anxious city slowly becoming itself again.
content: First dates are once again happening in coffee shops, not on computer screens. The East Village has resumed being the place on a Friday night to find a sweaty mass of bodies snaking out of bars into streets. The vaccination rate is rising.

description: Most policies are issued by the government, which plans to change the way it prices its policies in the fall to better reflect climate risks.
content: This year’s hurricane season began early, with a named storm forming before the official start on June 1, and it is expected to be active. If you lack flood insurance, especially if you live near the coast, this is the time to consider it.

description: Summit meetings are always full of prepackaged “deliverables,’’ but stage management always works better when there’s an actual stage.

description: The new building, once a Safeway grocery store, is just around the corner from the museum’s current home in Santa Fe, N.M., and is about 47,000 square feet bigger.
content: For nearly 25 years, Georgia O’Keeffe, an iconic American modernist painter, has been honored in a museum that is not much bigger than two tennis courts.

title: U.S. Senate Confirms First Muslim Federal District Judge
description: The judge, Zahid N. Quraishi of New Jersey, said after his selection by President Biden, “Candidly, I would prefer to be the hundredth, if not the thousandth.”
content: Zahid N. Quraishi, a federal magistrate judge and the son of Pakistani immigrants, was confirmed by the U.S. Senate for a federal judgeship in New Jersey on Thursday, becoming the first Muslim Federal District Court judge in the nation’s history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yewande Komolafe
title: Okra, a Summer Staple With So Much to Share
description: Approaching okra creatively will broaden the complexity and flavors of your cooking. A one-pan spiced shrimp dinner proves it.
content: Okra is a kind of culinary education bound in sturdy, ridged pods. When prepared with the right techniques, okra can take on crispy, silky and stretchy textures few ingredients can replicate. Learning how to approach okra in creative ways — taking cues from its uses in the cuisines of Africa, Central and South America, Asia, and the Middle East — can broaden the complexity and flavors of your cooking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: The C.D.C. is investigating nearly 800 cases of rare heart problems following immunization.
description: More than half of the cases were reported in people ages 12 to 24. Not all are likely to be verified or related to vaccines, and experts believe the benefits of immunization far outweigh the risk of these complications.
content: Federal officials are reviewing nearly 800 cases of rare heart problems following immunization with the coronavirus vaccines made by Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna, according to data presented at a vaccine safety meeting on Thursday.

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: Sam Altman on the A.I. Revolution, Trillionaires and the Future of Political Power
description: Will A.I. give us the lives of leisure we long for — or usher in a feudal dystopia? It depends.
content: “The technological progress we make in the next 100 years will be far larger than all we’ve made since we first controlled fire and invented the wheel,” writes Sam Altman in his essay “Moore’s Law for Everything.” “This revolution will generate enough wealth for everyone to have what they need, if we as a society manage it responsibly.”

title: British Restaurants Are Battling a Staff Crisis, Worsened by Brexit
description: A shortage of workers is forcing restaurants to turn away eager customers and confront a bigger problem: how to make hospitality an industry where people want to work.
content: LONDON — In the wealthy central London enclave of Belgravia, where a two-bedroom apartment is advertised for 1.7 million pounds, or $2.4 million, and Maseratis and Bentleys line the streets, the battle for restaurant staff has become downright underhanded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: The value of Rupert Murdoch’s racy The Sun newspaper is written down to nothing.
description: One of Britain’s most-read tabloids, it suffered in the pandemic because of a decline in print advertising and lost circulation.
content: After decades as one of Britain’s most-read tabloids, Rupert Murdoch’s The Sun newspaper has had its value written down to zero, financial accounts filed on Thursday said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: What to Know About Mask Rules in California
description: Friday: Vaccinated Californians will mostly be able to go mask-free. But there’s still some confusion. Also: News about California Today.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker
title: An Oregon lawmaker is ejected from office for helping a crowd breach the State Capitol.
description: The Oregon House voted 59 to 1 to remove Representative Mike Nearman, a Republican, for his actions in December.
content: Lawmakers in Oregon ejected one of their colleagues from office for the first time in state history late Thursday night, voting 59 to 1 to oust Representative Mike Nearman for his role in helping a far-right crowd breach the State Capitol in December.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Braff
title: The Officiant Finally Becomes the Bride
description: Victoria Hogan has married thousands of couples in Las Vegas, and after meeting Stephen Fetterusso, got to experience her own wedding.
content: It was the classic tale with a twist: Victoria Hogan was always the officiant, never the bride.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan Pinker
title: There Is More to Us Than Just Our Brains
description: In “The Extended Mind” Annie Murphy Paul explores all the ways our thinking is shaped by external forces, from physical sensations to the role of other people and their brains.
content: THE EXTENDED MINDThe Power of Thinking Outside the BrainBy Annie Murphy Paul
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yotam Ottolenghi
title: Oven Fries by Way of Bahrain, New York and London
description: The ‘Bahrain-made, New York-trained’ Noor Murad of the Ottolenghi test kitchen brings her experiences and memories to this latest dish, as rich as it is comforting.
content: LONDON — I’ve been waiting for the perfect dish to reintroduce my test kitchen colleague Noor Murad. I think this may be it. We’ve been working together for a while now, so I could have chosen from many recipes. But this one, for oven fries with tahini yogurt and smoky-sweet nuts, especially says “Noor” to me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Question Looms Over This Year’s Group of 7: Where Are All the Protesters?
description: It’s challenging to be an activist this year, what with the pandemic, a hermetically sealed summit and a new American president who is hard to get too worked up over.
content: FALMOUTH, England — It was no diaper-clad Donald J. Trump, but this year’s Group of 7 meeting got its own inflatable mascot on Friday: a floating blimp that caricatures President Biden and Prime Minister Boris Johnson, holding hands and waving, each wearing swim trunks in the design of their national flags.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew J. Bacevich
title: Secrets That Were No Secret, Lessons That Were Not Learned
description: As a soldier in Vietnam, I already knew what the Pentagon Papers revealed. In the years since, America's leaders have repeated the same mistakes.
content: When The New York Times began publishing the Pentagon Papers 50 years ago, I don’t recall giving the story much attention. As a young Army lieutenant serving in South Vietnam, I did not need a classified account of America’s reckless involvement in the war to tell me that I was participating in a misbegotten enterprise. Abundant evidence was in plain sight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sullivan
title: Plan to Revive I.R.S. ‘Wealth Squad’ Puts the Richest on Notice
description: President Biden has proposed a big increase in the I.R.S. budget for enforcement. So the best advice in dealing with the new scrutiny? Keep better records.
content: Many legal tax strategies that the wealthy have long used to minimize their taxes are likely to come under new scrutiny by the Internal Revenue Service.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: Juilliard Students Protest Tuition Increase With Marches and Music
description: After occupying parts of the school, some students were barred from entering the building. So they took the demonstration outside.
content: The Juilliard School, one of the world’s leading performing arts conservatories, is better known for recitals than picket lines. But students protesting a planned tuition increase occupied parts of its Lincoln Center campus this week and, when they were later barred from entering a school building, led music- and dance-filled protests on West 65th Street.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: How a Nonprofit Soccer Leader Spends His Sundays
description: When Ray Selvadurai, the director of coaching for the Manhattan Soccer Club, is not on the pitch, he’s with his daughter in the Bronx.
content: Manhattan Soccer Club is one of the largest youth soccer organizations in New York. Its home base for play is Randalls Island in Manhattan, where around 1,500 members between 5 and 23 train and compete on its 31 soccer fields. Ray Selvadurai, who has been with the club for 23 years, is its director of coaching.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley
title: Parties Settle in Legal Fight Over Robert Indiana’s Legacy
description: The artist’s estate, a company that licensed the sale of some of his works and a former caretaker had been fighting in court since the time of the artist’s death in 2018.
content: After three years of courtroom hostilities, the estate of the artist Robert Indiana and the artist’s former business partner said Friday that they had agreed to settle the legal disputes that cost the estate millions of dollars and clouded the market for a man known for such works as the sculpture, “LOVE.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Canada’s Muslims Call For Action Against Islamophobia
description: After the targeted killing of a Muslim family in London, Ontario, the community is demanding a summit on Islamophobia.
content: First came the shocking discovery of the remains of 215 Indigenous children on the grounds of a former residential school in Kamloops. Then it was compounded this week when a motorist used a black pickup truck to target a Muslim family in London, Ontario, killing four members of the family and seriously injuring one by running them over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Bucks Slow Down Nets to Trim Series Lead to 2-1
description: A grinding game of defense allowed Giannis Antetokounmpo and Khris Middleton to shine in a 86-83 win over the Nets.
content: To get a much needed win on Thursday, the Milwaukee Bucks did the opposite of what got the team so far in the playoffs: They slowed down their play.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Oken
title: ‘Betty’ Skates Into Season 2
description: The young stars of the HBO skate comedy discuss how pandemic-era New York shaped the new season. “Our show grows with us and changes with our world,” Ajani Russell said.
content: On a recent morning at Golconda Skate Park, beneath the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, the stars of “Betty” alternated between their defining pursuits: skating and, well, being stars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Reyes
title: Their Essential Interest in Common Was Each Other
description: As they got to know each other better, Emily Capilouto and Dr. James Harb realized they had more similarities than differences.
content: On paper, Emily Capilouto and Dr. James Harb didn’t seem to have much in common when they connected through the dating app Bumble in 2018 and agreed to meet for a first date in Birmingham, Ala., where both lived.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: What to Do This Weekend
description: “In the Heights” and strawberries.
content: Welcome. Set the tone for the weekend with “In the Heights,” Jon M. Chu’s long-awaited film adaptation of Lin-Manuel Miranda and Quiara Alegría Hudes’s Tony-winning Broadway musical. A.O. Scott didn’t want it to end: “After more than a year of desultory streaming, anemic entertainment and panicky doomscrolling,” he writes, “it’s a dream come true.” It’s in theaters and streaming on HBO Max.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Worthen
title: Is There a Way to Dial Down the Political Hatred?
description: Humans may be wired to need some kind of faith, but it doesn’t have to be like this.
content: President Biden tends to hammer on the theme of national unity, often in theological terms. On Memorial Day, he described the ongoing battle for the “soul of America,” a conflict between “our worst instincts — which we’ve seen of late — and our better angels. Between ‘Me first’ and ‘We the people.’” In January, in his Inaugural Address, he quoted St. Augustine: “A people was a multitude defined by the common objects of their love.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gisela Williams
title: In Rome, an Apartment Rich in Color and History Opens to the Public
description: One of the leading figures of Italian Futurism, Giacomo Balla turned his home into proof of his idea that art should live in all things.
content: ON A SPRING evening in Rome, the filmmaking duo Ila Bêka and Louise Lemoine entered Casa Balla, the former apartment of the early 20th-century artist Giacomo Balla, with flashlights in hand. The U-shaped three-bedroom flat, located on the fourth floor of a nondescript mid-20th-century building, had hardly been touched since the 1990s, after the deaths of Balla’s daughters — Elica in 1993 and Luce a year later — both of whom lived in the apartment their entire lives. Bêka’s and Lemoine’s lights revealed a long hallway painted with amoebalike shapes in bright yellow and green that seemed to dance against a peach-colored background. Dozens of square and wildly colorful abstract paintings were mounted on the upper portion of the walls, concealing exposed water pipes and little cubbies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe, Jeremiah M. Bogert, Jr. and Shelby Knowles
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Reopening in photos.
content: With vaccination rates rising and virus cases declining, there is a hopefulness to this summer that feels exciting and unique. Millions of Americans, after 15 months of heartbreak and sacrifice, are returning to prepandemic activities for the first time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger
title: Prepare to Pay More for Uber and Lyft Rides
description: The companies say they are charging extra because they don’t have enough drivers to match rebounding customer demand.
content: A few weeks after receiving the second dose of a coronavirus vaccine, Debora Lima returned to an old routine: She pulled out her phone and requested an Uber ride so she could meet friends for dinner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: What is the G7 summit, and why does it matter?
description: The nations in the club are the world’s wealthiest large democracies, close allies and major trading partners that account for about half of the global economy.
content: For three days, beginning Friday, some of the world’s most powerful leaders are descending on a small Cornish village for a series of meetings as part of the Group of 7 summit, which brings together the heads of Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan and the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere and Noah Weiland
title: F.D.A. Tells Johnson & Johnson That 60 Million Vaccine Doses Cannot Be Used
description: The agency has not decided whether to allow a troubled vaccine factory in Baltimore to reopen.
content: WASHINGTON — Federal regulators said on Friday that millions of doses of Johnson & Johnson’s coronavirus vaccine produced at a troubled Baltimore factory could not be used, the latest in a series of setbacks for a company whose single-shot vaccine was once considered crucial to the nation’s inoculation campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf
title: A Path of Forgiveness After Unimaginable Loss in Iraq
description: An engineer’s wife, daughter and other family members were killed in a misguided airstrike by the U.S.-led coalition. But Basim Razzo would rather sow understanding than hatred.
content: ERBIL, Iraq — Basim Razzo’s apartment in the Iraqi Kurdish city of Erbil is pristine, with none of the clutter of most family homes. The spotless kitchen cupboards hold cans of Maxwell House coffee, a brand he and his wife, Mayada Taka, became fond of when they lived in the United States in the 1980s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Two Montana Sweethearts Were Fatally Shot in 1956. The Case Was Just Solved.
description: The Cascade County Sheriff’s Office said it appeared to be the oldest homicide case in the United States to be solved with genetic genealogy.
content: When Detective Sgt. Jon Kadner of the Cascade County Sheriff’s Office in Montana was told in 2012 that he was being put in charge of the investigation into a long-unsolved double homicide, the case was already more than 50 years old.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: The Noodles You Need
description: Lean on Judy Kim’s cool chile-oil noodles recipe all summer long.
content: Friends came by to visit last weekend, and my three-year-old announced that we had “a fabulous pineapple” for the occasion. I don’t know where she got the phrase “fabulous pineapple,” but it was true: The pineapple, which I bought to garnish piña coladas, was fabulous. There was plenty left over for making dishes like the pineapple-marinated chicken below, an exuberant meal for the summer to come. And if this heat keeps up in New York, Judy Kim’s chile-oil noodles are next in my rotation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Cermatori
title: How a Family Transformed the Look of European Theater
description: The Bibienas, the focus of an exhibition at the Morgan Library & Museum, dominated Baroque theatrical design.
content: Many of us have not seen the inside of a theater in well over a year. But as performance spaces around the country are on the verge of reopening, the Morgan Library & Museum is offering a quietly astonishing reminder of what we’ve been missing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Geneva Abdul
title: German Parliament Backs ‘Milestone’ Gender Quota for Company Boards
description: The legislation requires many public companies in Germany to have at least one woman on the supervisory board.
content: Germany on Friday moved to ensure that women are represented in the upper echelons of some of Europe’s largest publicly traded companies, advancing a measure in Parliament that would set a quota for women on management boards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Five Science-Fiction Movies to Stream Now
description: From “Undergods” to “Greenland,” a selection of world-altering films to keep you guessing.
content: It’s hard to define science fiction as a genre when the goal posts keep moving and yesterday’s far-fetched scenario becomes today’s headline. It helps to think of any movie that asks “What if?” as belonging to the genre. And this month’s selection of streaming under-the-radar science fiction will make you ponder many more questions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Christensen
title: New in Paperback: ‘Summer’ and ‘The Dragons, the Giant, the Women’
description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
content: SUMMER, by Ali Smith. (Anchor, 400 pp., $17.) Dwight Garner called the finale of Smith’s seasonal quartet “a prose poem in praise of memory, forgiveness, getting the joke and seizing the moment.” Featuring teenage siblings “OK boomer”-ing their parents as well as some characters from the previous novels in the series, the plot is hard to pin down. “To properly enter this novel,” Garner wrote, “you’ve got to be willing to get a bit lost.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Burdick
title: Where the Grass is Greener, Except When It’s ‘Nonfunctional Turf’
description: Plus, mammoths in Vegas, watermelon snow, Miami’s looming sea wall and more in the Friday edition of the Science Times newsletter.
content: If you’re looking for a sign of the End Times, here’s one: Las Vegas, the city where seemingly anything and everything is condoned, has made grass — the ornamental kind — illegal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner, Nick Corasaniti and Reid J. Epstein
title: Garland Pledges Renewed Efforts to Protect Voting Rights
description: The attorney general’s commitment served notice to Republican-led states imposing new voting restrictions, and included a vow to protect the voting rights of people of color.
content: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Merrick B. Garland laid out an expansive plan on Friday for protecting voting rights, announcing that the Justice Department would double enforcement staff on the issue, scrutinize new state laws that seek to curb voter access and take action if it sees a violation of federal law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: For Australia’s prime minister, his visit to Cornwall is a homecoming — of sorts.
description: One of the leader’s ancestors was sent from the area in southwestern England to Australia two centuries ago with hundreds of other convicts.
content: More than two centuries after his ancestor was cast out of Cornwall for stealing and sent to Australia with hundreds of other convicts, Scott Morrison returned to the area on Friday as prime minister of Australia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Rezo Gabriadze, Who Created Magic Out of Puppetry, Dies at 84
description: His productions, vivid and fanciful, played all over the world, including at Lincoln Center.
content: Rezo Gabriadze, a playwright, screenwriter and director whose fanciful avant-garde stage works, many using puppets, were presented at the Lincoln Center Festival in New York and numerous other outlets as well as at the theater named for him in his home country, Georgia, died on Sunday in its capital, Tbilisi. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: E.R. visits following suspected suicide attempts rose among teen girls during the pandemic.
description: “The findings from this study suggest more severe distress among young females than has been identified in previous reports,” the C.D.C. said.
content: Emergency room visits following suspected suicide attempts by teenage girls spiked in the first months of 2021, compared with rates in 2019, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Bernstein and Denny Lee
title: Black Ties and Polka Dots at the New York Botanical Garden
description: And Pioneer Works hosts a dinner with Maggie Gyllenhaal, Peter Sarsgaard and David Byrne.
content: The first major black-tie gala of the not quite post-pandemic era took place June 3, when the New York Botanical Garden held a spring fund-raiser.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Summer Reading Contest Week 1: What Got Your Attention in The Times This Week?
description: To participate, submit your response here by June 18 at 9 a.m. Eastern. This week’s winners will be announced on June 29.
content: Our 12th Annual Summer Reading Contest begins!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: ‘Worlds Fair Inn’ Review: You Can Check Out Anytime You Like
description: A lurid story about the serial killer H.H. Holmes gets an absurdist spin at the Axis Theater Company.
content: What have we learned from all of those dark nights, and will anything have changed now that the lights are coming on again? These are the definitive questions of this odd moment, as theater begins its piecemeal reopening. “Worlds Fair Inn,” a new play at Axis Theater Company, offers one deflating response: nothing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Texas Says It Will Build Border Wall With Mexico
description: “Texas will not sit idly by as this crisis grows,” Gov. Greg Abbott said of border crossings, while offering few details about the wall.
content: McALLEN, Texas — Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas said on Thursday that the state would build a border wall with Mexico, providing few specifics about construction that would extend one of former President Donald J. Trump’s favored projects.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: What Should I Wear to a Funeral?
description: A reader wonders what is appropriate funeral attire.
content: This is indeed a sad situation but one I think more and more of us may experience as vaccine progress allows us to gather again, not just for celebrations but for the group mourning and memorializing that was denied us last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar
title: Departures of Police Officers Accelerated During a Year of Protests
description: Retirements nationwide were up by 45 percent and resignations by 18 percent in the 12-month period ending in April.
content: Police departments face severe challenges in retaining and recruiting officers, according to new data outlining the steady exodus from an occupation that was the target of protests last year after several high-profile police killings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Concepción de León
title: What to Know About Testing and Vaccine Requirements for Travel
description: Do you need to be vaccinated or have a negative Covid-19 test for your next trip? Check this guide before traveling domestically or abroad.
content: As vaccinations ramp up and regulations loosen for people in the United States, many are planning travel for summer and beyond, with experts predicting that July 4 will be the biggest travel weekend since the beginning of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Martha White, 99, Dies; Before Rosa Parks, She Sparked a Bus Boycott
description: The 1953 protest in Baton Rouge, triggered by her ejection from a bus for sitting in a “whites only” section, became a template for Martin Luther King.
content: Martha White, a Black housekeeper in Baton Rouge, La., was bone-weary coming home from work one day in 1953. As she climbed aboard a city bus, she saw only one seat left, in the “whites only” section at the front. She took it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosalie R. Radomsky
title: In Translation: A Friendship Redefined
description: After Maddy Belloff joined Danny Martinez for his family vacation in Colombia, she went from “mi amiga,” my friend, to “mi novia,” my girlfriend.
content: Madeline Rhiana Belloff was at the ready with Red Bull Energy Drinks, Sour Patch Kids candy and Goldfish crackers, while Daniel Alexander Martinez fortified them with sandwiches from the local deli when they often studied together at Columbia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: Fireworks Are Back in N.Y.C. Are We in for Another Loud Summer?
description: It's a seasonal tradition in the city's streets, but the displays might not have the same energy  they had last year.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons and Dana Rubinstein
title: 5 takeaways from the latest Democratic debate for New York mayor.
description: After the candidates piled on Eric Adams over his place of residence, the debate turned to more substantive issues like policing, congestion pricing and marijuana laws.
content: At least at first, the third major Democratic debate in the race for mayor of New York City focused on the story that has dominated the race this week: Where does Eric Adams live?
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Cost of Being an ‘Interchangeable Asian’ and How to Advocate for Your Well-Being at Work: The Week in Narrated Articles
description: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
content: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: Two Black Students Won School Honors. Then Came the Calls for a Recount.
description: After two white families claimed a grade calculation error, a Mississippi school added their children as co-valedictorian and co-salutatorian, reviving questions about race and equity.
content: At first, it seemed a joyous occasion. There was an audible gasp in the room, then boisterous cheering and applause when the announcement was made: Ikeria Washington and Layla Temple had been named 2021 valedictorian and salutatorian for West Point High School.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Pulitzer Prize: 2021 Winners List
description: From reporting on the coronavirus pandemic to an investigation of China’s internment of Uyghurs, here’s the full list of winners and finalists.
content: The Pulitzer committee honored The New York Times with the prestigious public service award for its “prescient and sweeping” coverage of the Covid-19 pandemic, particularly for filling “a data vacuum that helped local governments, health care providers, businesses and individuals to be better prepared and protected.” Read the coverage here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: E.P.A. to Review Rules on Soot Linked to Deaths, Which Trump Declined to Tighten
description: The Biden administration says it will consider tougher limits on a deadly air pollutant that disproportionately affects low-income and minority communities.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration will reconsider federal limits on fine industrial soot, one of the most common and deadliest forms of air pollution, with an eye toward imposing tough new rules on emissions from power plants, factories and other industrial facilities.The announcement, made Thursday by Michael S. Regan, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, comes after the Trump administration declined last year to tighten pollution limits, despite warnings from federal scientists and others that doing so could save more than 10,000 lives a year, particularly in urban areas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: A Fragile Israeli Coalition, With Some Underlying Glue
description: An agreement to return to democratic norms might be the one thing that holds together the disparate coalition facing a confidence vote on Sunday.
content: JERUSALEM — A new Israeli government united in its determination to oust Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, but in agreement on little else, is set to take office Sunday under a right-wing leader whose eight-party coalition includes the left and, for the first time, an independent Arab party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: It Covers the Field
description: Brooke Husic and Brian Thomas are outstanding in their collaborative debut.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This grid is fast-paced, even if you’re flummoxed at times; there are lots of activities in the clues and entries. Some are mordant, and I thought of a funny expression that I’d squirreled away at some point, “Attack of the Killer B’s,” referring both to 1-Down and our co-constructors, Brooke Husic and Brian Thomas. They’re both sharp and funny themeless experts, they came up with a really fun challenge here, and I am looking forward to more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher and Cao Li
title: China Accuses 32 in Ultramarathon Disaster, but Main Suspect Is Dead
description: Organizers of the May race, which claimed 21 lives, face criminal charges and disciplinary action. The man said to bear primary responsibility died in a fall from a high-rise this week.
content: BEIJING — Less than three weeks after 21 people died amid freezing rain and high winds during a 62-mile footrace in northwestern China, officials said on Friday that 31 people would be held responsible and that the leader of the county in which the ultramarathon was held had died in a fall from a high-rise building.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: The Artist vs. the Technocrat: A $2 Million Parable
description: Should a former C.E.O. of Twitter pay for the damaged artwork of one of the city’s last true bohemians? Faulty plumbing and clashing values erupt in SoHo.
content: In 1974, Dorothea Rockburne, 42 and Canadian, was enjoying the beginnings of success as an artist in late midcentury Manhattan. Two years earlier she had received a Guggenheim fellowship,  followed by an exhibit at the influential Lisson Gallery in London and an appearance on the cover of Artforum. Now the hardest years of motherhood and paycheck work behind her, she was preparing for a group show at the Museum of Modern Art, when the downtown building where she had lived and answered to her creative impulses for 16 years, was sold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: The Tortured Rhyme and Reason of Meghan Markle’s Picture Book Debut
description: In “The Bench,” the Duchess of Sussex takes on “the special relationship” of fathers and sons, and the daunting challenge of rhyming verse.
content: THE BENCHBy Meghan, the Duchess of SussexIllustrated by Christian Robinson
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Erin Griffith
title: A cruise ship required all aboard to be vaccinated. Then two passengers tested positive for the virus.
description: As large gatherings resume in the U.S., infections on a cruise ship and at a Bitcoin conference show the challenges of reopening.
content: Just as cruises resume after more than a year on pause, the industry is facing an immediate setback.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Reyes
title: First ‘the Group Thing,’ Then a Couple
description: Nicole Nelson and Kyle Kriewall attended several activities together with friends, but it would be months before a romance developed.
content: A cabin weekend, in February 2018, with perhaps a bit of hockey, some snowmobiling and football, and definitely with a big fire in the middle of Lake 26, in Danbury, Wis., is the event that Nicole Nelson and Kyle Kriewall mark as the beginning of their story.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: Biden plans to restore protections for Tongass National Forest that were stripped away by Trump.
description: The Trump administration allowed road building in Alaska’s Tongass National Forest, a pristine wilderness. President Biden intends to change those plans.
content: The Biden administration plans to restore environmental protections to Alaska’s Tongass National Forest that had been stripped away at the end of the Trump administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: What Drives Joe Manchin? Frustrated Democrats Can Look to West Virginia.
description: The senator has become a lightning rod in his party and a major obstacle to President Biden’s agenda. In his home state, his stubborn belief in bipartisanship is recognized as the core of his being.
content: FARMINGTON, W.Va. — Decades ago, John Manchin Jr., a civic leader in a small coal town in West Virginia, lent his support to a Democrat running for Congress. His candidate lost to a Republican named Arch Moore Jr.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Pérez-Peña
title: Queen Elizabeth, Prince Charles and Prince William joined G7 leaders for dinner.
description: The royal family’s presence around the summit meeting will be unusually strong this year.
content: Queen Elizabeth II, Prince Charles and Prince William joined Group of 7 leaders on Friday for a reception and dinner, as the royal family makes an unusually robust presence around the edges of the annual summit meeting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere, Noah Weiland and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: The F.D.A. tells Johnson & Johnson that about 60 million doses made at a troubled plant cannot be used.
description: The doses, produced at a Baltimore factory under federal review, could have been contaminated.
content: WASHINGTON — Federal regulators have told Johnson & Johnson that about 60 million doses of its coronavirus vaccine produced at a troubled Baltimore factory cannot be used because of possible contamination, according to people familiar with the situation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: China’s Censorship Widens to Hong Kong’s Vaunted Film Industry, With Global Implications
description: The city’s government said it would block the distribution of films that are deemed to undermine national security, bringing the territory more in line with mainland Chinese rules.
content: For decades, Hong Kong’s movie industry has enthralled global audiences with balletic shoot-em-ups, epic martial-arts fantasies, chopsocky comedies and shadow-drenched romances. Now, under orders from Beijing, local officials will scrutinize such works with an eye toward safeguarding the People’s Republic of China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: How to Reopen Offices Safely
description: Flush the taps, focus on indoor air quality and consider getting creative about staff schedules.
content: For the last 15 months, many American offices sat essentially empty. Conference rooms and cubicles went unused, elevators uncalled, files untouched. Whiteboards became time capsules. Succulents had to fend for themselves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Samuel Earle
title: Boris Johnson Is a Terrible Leader. It Doesn’t Matter.
description: Britain’s prime minister is slapdash, venal, incompetent — and unassailably popular.
content: LONDON — Boris Johnson, Britain’s freewheeling, clownish prime minister, is about to play host.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Murphy Paul
title: How to Think Outside Your Brain
description: The days when we could do it all in our heads are  over.
content: Years ago, when I was in college, I visited the dorm room of a fellow student I was dating. On the wall above his desk he had posted a handwritten sign. “Just do it,” it read, in blocky letters. Nike’s slogan was intended to capture an attitude toward athletic endeavors, but this undergrad was applying it to mental exertions. I pictured him sitting at his desk, working hour after hour on his German verb conjugations or econ problem sets. At some point he would become restless, lose focus — then look up at his sign, set his jaw and turn back to his studies, determined to crush them like a 100-meter dash.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Herb Sturz, a Quiet Force in the Life of New York City, Dies at 90
description: His agenda and reach, in government and out, extended from criminal justice to urban planning, though his constituency — prisoners, the homeless, the elderly and more — hardly knew his name.
content: Herb Sturz, a self-taught expert in criminal justice and urban planning who profoundly but inconspicuously influenced public policy across a remarkably broad range of issues in New York and beyond, died on Thursday in Tucson, Ariz. He was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos and Charlie Savage
title: Justice Dept. watchdog and Senate Democrats promise to investigate secret seizure of lawmakers’ data.
description: After a report by The New York Times, officials at the Justice Department and in Congress said seizing data from lawmakers is nearly unheard-of outside of corruption investigations.
content: The Justice Department’s independent inspector general opened an inquiry on Friday into the Trump administration’s secret seizure of data from House Democrats and reporters as prosecutors sought to hunt down the sources of leaks of classified information.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Paton
title: Matty Bovan on Winning the 2021 Woolmark Prize
description: The British designer talks knits, sustainability and why young talents must have courage of their creative convictions.
content: Matty Bovan presented his first solo catwalk show at London Fashion Week in 2018. One of Britain’s most colorful fashion stars, with distinctive rainbow streaks in his hair, he is known for his bold palettes and intricate knits. This week, Mr. Bovan won the 2021 International Woolmark Prize and the Karl Lagerfeld Award for Innovation, becoming only the second designer to win both awards in the same year. (The first was Edward Crutchley in 2019.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariro Mzezewa
title: Want to Go to Hawaii? Be Prepared.
description: Interest in visiting the islands is running high, but the price of paradise can be multiple Covid tests, expensive stints in quarantine, long waits in line and more.
content: Vaccinated travelers may soon be able to travel to Hawaii without testing or quarantining, some eight months after the state instituted its stern Safe Travels program.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Tackling Vaccine Complacency Close to Home
description: People like my parents could help speed up Australia’s vaccine rollout — if they ever stop putting it off.
content: For the past two weeks, I’ve been trying to nudge my parents into getting the vaccine. They’ve been eligible since the beginning of May and can book an appointment through their G.P. whenever they want. They’re going to get it. They’ve just been putting it off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: It’s not officially summer yet, but you can still get to grilling with a glass of sweet tea in hand.
content: Good morning. It’s not high summer yet. It’s not even summer yet. But my thoughts about cooking are running very July. I’d like to be grilling this weekend, in a park or sideyard, or down on a beach burying clams and lobsters and corn under a cloak of coals. I’d like to have some fat Jersey tomatoes warm from the sun, and I’d like to slice them thick, douse them with brown butter and serve them with toast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor and Jesus Jiménez
title: Board Approves Removal of ‘Negro’ From 16 Place Names in Texas
description: An Interior Department committee’s decision to allow the renaming of the sites comes nearly 30 years after Texas lawmakers first voted to change the names.
content: A federal board on Thursday approved the renaming of 16 sites in Texas whose names include the word “Negro,” a change long sought by politicians and activists in the state, but one that will affect only a small fraction of the hundreds of racist names of towns and geographical features that remain in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: She Sought Change at the Manhattan D.A.’s Office. Now She Wants to Lead It.
description: Lucy Lang has spent most of her career as a criminal-justice reformer. But is she too close to the system to bring about real change?
content: Lucy Lang is a squeaky wheel, a meddler, a self-described noodge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: China Still Buys American DNA Equipment for Xinjiang Despite Blocks
description: The U.S. government has long tried to prevent the sales over concerns about rights abuses and surveillance. Documents show those efforts have failed.
content: The police in the Chinese region of Xinjiang are still buying hundreds of thousands of dollars’ worth of American DNA equipment despite warnings from the U.S. government that the sale of such technologies could be used to enable human rights abuses in the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlos Aguilar
title: They Fought to Make ‘In the Heights’ Both Dreamlike and Authentic
description: The creative team of Lin-Manuel Miranda, Quiara Alegría Hudes and Jon M. Chu explain what it took to create a euphoric spectacle that stayed true to its cultural roots.
content: Lin-Manuel Miranda still believes it was a miracle that “In the Heights,” the musical homage to Latino culture through the lens of the Washington Heights neighborhood, made it to Broadway. Back in 2008, before striving for inclusion became the entertainment industry standard, he and the playwright Quiara Alegría Hudes were unknowns peddling a joyful narrative about unseen people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Hoberman
title: A History of the Hollywood Chronicle in 10 Books
description: Want to learn more about how the movies were made? These books are a good place to start.
content: The history of Hollywood is a history of 20th century America — more precisely, it’s a saga of mass-produced fantasy co-starring the folks who made the movies and those who consumed them. No single book can hope to tell the story. “Not half a dozen men have ever been able to keep the whole equation of pictures in their heads,” F. Scott Fitzgerald wrote in the first chapter of his Hollywood novel, “The Last Tycoon.” Still, these books, published over seven decades, even as the movie industry itself become a legend, offer a prismatic view of what used to be called the Dream Factory. Each is a part of the equation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Baron Davis Directs Now. If There’s a ‘Space Jam 3,’ He Wants In.
description: The former N.B.A. star’s first movie, “Domino: Battle of the Bones,” is as in-your-face as his playing style. And he’s got plenty more big-screen ideas.
content: Baron Davis has long been a showman. During his N.B.A. career, which lasted from 1999 to 2012, Davis was known as one of the flashiest stars in the league. His best-known play was a 2007 playoff dunk for the Golden State Warriors on the Utah Jazz’s Andrei Kirilenko, which was so instantly memorable that Davis didn’t bother arguing the technical foul he received for celebrating too vociferously. That has long been Davis: an over-the-top talent ready to entertain at a moment’s notice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shashank Bengali
title: McDonald’s in Indonesia are forced to close after a ‘BTS Meal’ frenzy that violated Covid measures.
description: Crowds of delivery drivers responding to a rush of online orders violated safe distancing measures as they flooded unprepared restaurants.
content: Several McDonald’s outlets in Indonesia were forced to close this week after a special “BTS Meal,” named for the wildly popular Korean boy band, drew crowds of delivery drivers that violated safe distancing measures, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos and Charlie Savage
title: Justice Dept. Watchdog to Investigate Seizure of Democrats’ Data
description: Democrats denounced the Trump administration’s seizure of lawmakers’ data as an abuse of power and called on Republicans to back the congressional inquiry.
content: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department’s independent inspector general opened an investigation on Friday into the decision by federal prosecutors to secretly seize the data of House Democrats and reporters as investigators hunted down who was leaking classified information early in the Trump administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charanna Alexander
title: Love Letter: A 95th Birthday Celebration and Wedding Cake Too
description: And: Dating as a trans woman.
content: The pandemic made dating a lot more complicated for many, but it didn’t stop Joy Morrow-Nulton and John Shults Jr. from falling in love, getting engaged and tying the knot. The couple, both 95, met through Ms. Morrow-Nulton’s son in May 2019 and began a courtship that included frequent lunch dates, mostly in their homes. By February, they were vaccinated and engaged. Their wedding on May 22 doubled as a celebration of their love and their 95th birthdays that same month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cara Giaimo
title: Glacier Blood? Watermelon Snow? Whatever It’s Called, Snow Shouldn’t Be So Red.
description: Researchers are starting to investigate the species that drive alpine algal blooms to better understand their causes and effects.
content: Winter through spring, the French Alps are wrapped in austere white snow. But as spring turns to summer, the stoic slopes start to blush. Parts of the snow take on bright colors: deep red, rusty orange, lemonade pink. Locals call this “sang de glacier,” or “glacier blood.” Visitors sometimes go with “watermelon snow.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Katori Hall Wins Drama Pulitzer for ‘The Hot Wing King’
description: The play, which had its run cut short because of the pandemic, centers on a kitchen in Memphis, where a man is trying to concoct award-winning chicken wings.
content: Katori Hall, who has told stirring stories about Black life in America both onstage and onscreen, has won the Pulitzer Prize for Drama for “The Hot Wing King,” a family dramedy that centers on a man’s quest to make award-winning chicken wings while personal conflict swirls around him.

content: As a young dancer, Katy Pyle related to Giselle, the ballet heroine who is betrayed by a nobleman. That — and a weak heart — causes the character to go mad and die. For Pyle, the draw was Giselle’s unwavering dedication to dance, specifically to ballet.

Clinger Jr., a nine-term Republican congressman from Pennsylvania who vigorously pursued two investigations into wrongdoing by the Clinton administration and two decades later said that Donald J. Trump, his party’s nominee, was unqualified to be president, died on May 28 in Naples, Fla. He was 92.

title: First a ‘Little White Lie,’ Then a Solid Commitment
description: Summer Hofford and Dr. Sujay Kulshrestha met for drinks after connecting on Tinder. Their first round went smoothly. The second, not so much.

title: Biden May Be the Calm Between Two Storms

content: Since most of us are sleeping better in the quietude of a sane presidency, it’s tempting to ignore the current craziness of the Republican Party. Between the QAnon wackos, the anti-vaccine conspiracy theorists, the voter suppression hard-liners, the coup enthusiasts and the election deniers, the party is showing a mash-up of madness.

author: By Nicole Rudick
title: Nearly 70 Years Later, ‘Invisible Man’ Is Still Inspiring Visual Artists
description: Ralph Ellison’s classic 1952 novel has influenced not just writers but photographers, sculptors and painters, all grappling with what it means to be seen.
content: In 1952, the photographer Gordon Parks worked with Ralph Ellison to translate the writer’s novel, “Invisible Man,” published earlier that year, into a series of images for Life magazine. One of the photographs depicts the book’s nameless narrator in his retreat beneath the city, amid the 1,369 light bulbs that, he tells the reader, “illuminated the blackness of my invisibility.” In Parks’s photograph, the lights are arrayed on the walls behind the figure in a modernist and rhythmic arrangement that reads as an extension of the music emanating from his two turntables (presumably Louis Armstrong, whom the narrator listens to while eating vanilla ice cream and sloe gin). The world up above — represented by tiny lights nearly swallowed up by the night — barely exists by comparison. But his clean, well-lighted place is a beginning, not an ending. He is biding his time. “A hibernation,” he says, “is a covert preparation for a more overt action.”

content: Daveed Diggs and Rafael Casal spent 9 years making “Blindspotting,” a dark and dreamlike 2018 buddy comedy about two friends grappling with police power in a rapidly gentrifying Oakland. author: By Sarah Weinman
title: Bang, Bang, You’re Dead
description: Murders abound in new novels from James Ellroy, Joe R. Lansdale, Laura McHugh and Leonardo Padura.
content: Reading James Ellroy is like being dragged into hell. This, I should stress, is both a compliment and a curse. The best of Ellroy seems to echo Dante’s “Inferno,” spiraling down circle after circle into the depths of mid-20th-century depravity where some greater meaning can be found — only to be upended and refracted. The worst of his work, however, devolves into monotony, the staccato prose more repetitive than ruminative, the characters sliding into ugly caricature.

author: By Thomas Rogers
title: Hearing the City, Too, at an Outdoor Berlin Film Festival
description: The movie soundtracks are competing with distant techno beats and the subway’s rattle at a coronavirus-proof edition of the annual event.
content: BERLIN — On Thursday night, the mood at the Hasenheide open-air movie theater was buoyant. An audience of about 200 people had assembled for a screening of “The Seed,” a German drama about a construction worker struggling to take care of his daughter in a rural part of the country.
